awd_titl_txt: A Belonging Intervention to Improve STEM Outcomes for Women and Underrepresented Students: A Randomized Controlled Trial at 22 Colleges
awd_abstract_narration:
This project consists of a large randomized-controlled trial (RCT) of a social psychological intervention with college students. The social-belonging intervention seeks to normalize the students' experience of struggle in the transition to college and provides productive strategies to help students perceive initial challenges with adjustment as relatively commonplace and not indicative of a lack of belonging. The project examines the experimental effects of the belonging intervention on the achievement and retention of underrepresented students in STEM courses and majors with more than 40,000 students across 22 colleges and universities. The project will explore how the effects of the belonging intervention vary based on the situational cues in students? local STEM settings and the visibility of those cues. It examines the experimental effects of the intervention on STEM persistence and performance (e.g., STEM grades, majoring, retention and graduation) among several stigmatized and underrepresented groups: women, underrepresented students of color, first-generation students, students with disabilities, and English-language learners. STEM majors and courses appear to constitute more threatening contexts for underrepresented groups than do other majors; yet they also offer opportunities for higher-paying jobs and contributions to the U.S. STEM workforce. Therefore, this project will focus on enhancing STEM persistence and performance among underrepresented groups through examination of the situational cues that engender identity threat and the experimental investigation of an identity-threat reducing intervention.

In a randomized controlled trial with over 40,000 first-year students at 22 colleges, this project will investigate how students from STEM-underrepresented groups (i.e., women, racial/ethnic minorities, first-generation college students, students with disabilities, and English-language learners) are affected by situational cues that signal their group may not be valued or expected to succeed in STEM settings. These feelings of social identity threat have been shown in decades of past research to negatively shape students' experiences of college, depress academic performance and persistence, and cause students to question their belonging in STEM and in college more generally. The researchers will assess the effectiveness of a large-scale pre-matriculation belonging intervention in improving the academic persistence and performance of students in STEM classes and fields. The treatment communicates that adversity and feelings of non-belonging are normative and temporary experiences in the transition to college that can improve by adopting productive social and academic strategies. The project will also investigate the boundary conditions of cue-induced identity threat by examining how STEM academic success is moderated by situational cues (e.g., numerical representation among students and faculty), and the visibility of the cues (e.g., whether such representation is easily assessed, as among women, or more difficult to assess, as among students with learning disabilities). The researchers will investigate how these effects play out in both broad-access and more selective colleges and among groups that past research has shown are affected by identity-threatening situational cues in STEM and who have shown improved outcomes from social-psychological interventions in STEM and non-STEM contexts.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GSE: Research on Gender in S&E

por.por_cntn:
This project consisted of the largest randomized controlled trial (RCT) of a social psychological intervention with college students conducted to date. This social-belonging intervention seeks to normalize the experience of struggle in the transition to college and provides productive strategies to help students perceive initial challenges with adjustment as relatively commonplace and not indicative of a lack of belonging.

The project examined the experimental effects of the belonging intervention on the achievement and retention of underrepresented students in STEM courses and majors with more than 40,000 students across 22 colleges and universities. This project is first to explore how the effects of the belonging intervention vary based on the situational cues in students’ local STEM settings (e.g., numerical representation; instructor’s identities) and the visibility of those cues.

This project examined the experimental effects of the intervention on STEM persistence and performance (e.g., STEM  grades, majoring, retention and graduation) among several stigmatized and underrepresented groups, including individuals with visible and invisible stigmatized identities. 

INTELLECTUAL MERIT:

 The major scientific and intellectual goals of the project included: 

(a) Implementing the intervention for the second cohort of students at our partner schools (COMPLETED). 

(b) Gathering student records data. (COMPLETED). 

(c) Gathering STEM classroom and instructor data from all 22 partner institutions (COMPLETED). 

(d) Cleaning, merging, and formating the 22-institution dataset (e.g. 40,000+ student records: students' group memberships, STEM course-taking, STEM majoring, STEM performance, overall retention and performance; belonging intervention condition, first-year spring survey measures; STEM classroom composition and STEM instructors' group memberships). (COMPLETED). 

(e) Conducting multi-level modeling and multiple regression analyses on students' STEM course-taking, majoring, performance and on overall GPA and retention to examine the effects of the intervention on these outcomes and among each subgroup of interest (COMPLETED).

(f) Writing papers and presenting results of the project to broad audiences (COMPLETED). 

BROADER IMPACTS:

Our findings showed that the belonging intervention significantly boosted the first-semester STEM GPA, as well as end-of-first-year GPA (and even, in some cases, year 2 GPA post-intervention), among students from disadvantaged social backgrounds. This is the first evidence apart from our pilot study that reveals the belonging intervention has such an effect in STEM learning environments.

Though the intervention does not target STEM specifically, our hypothesis was that the intervention reduces identity threat when it is present in college settings. If this is true, then we reasoned that the intervention should be most effective in contexts where identity threat is high; that is, in introductory STEM courses. Our findings supported this prediction. 

We found that results do emerge for those with invisible identities (e.g., mental, cognitive, learning disabilities). We also found promising findings for students with intersectional identities--in particular among women and URM students with other forms of disadvantaged identities (English language learner identities, first-generation students, etc.). 

We found exciting class-level and instructor-level moderator effects for both visible and invisible identity groups. Namely, women and URM/first generation students both reported more positive psychological experiences and/or better academic outcomes when institutional cues (such as a higher proportion of same-identity classmates or the presence of a same-identity instructor) demonstrated that “people like them” belonged and could succeed in their organization or field. These papers are among the first to demonstrate the importance of these cues, at this scale, on students’ psychological and academic outcomes. Moreover, these findings are unique in their ability to example the effect of varying cues that students are exposed to on their individual course grades (e.g., the gender of their different course instructors on their performance in each of those courses). Papers discussing these findings are published. and in press highly-read journals. 

This work has also had broad impact on other disciplines. Our theory, methods, and results are being disseminated in social psychology, cognitive psychology, social work, public health, chemistry, biology, physics, microbiology, and education. Belonging interventions are starting to be discussed and written about in these fields and our work is leading that discussion given the sample size and breadth of schools/universities who have participated in that work. 

Finally, this project has had broad impact on the development of human resources in STEM. With the first-semester and Y1 post-intervention STEM GPA findings, we are seeing that more disadvantaged students are pursuing and persisting in STEM course-taking and majors over time, as a function of the belonging intervention. 

Also, we have had an impact on human resource development through the mentoring and advancement of the graduate students, postdocs, and a statistician who have worked on this project. Two of our graduate assistants were accepted into PhD programs. Our three postdocs are all now assistant professors on the tenure track.


Last Modified: 11/29/2023
Modified by: Mary C Murphy

This project examined the experimental effects of the intervention on STEM persistence and performance (e.g., STEM grades, majoring, retention and graduation) among several stigmatized and underrepresented groups, including individuals with visible and invisible stigmatized identities.
